Dialogue.NPCText:
Before you dances Eru, her feet barely disturbing the soft earth, ribbons and petals fluttering with each motion. She pauses, eyes bright and curious.

"Greetings, friend of the forest. Have you come to listen to the spirits, or perhaps to weave a new story of your own?"

Option.text: I wish to hear a story of the Verdant Tribes.
Can you tell me about the Hinokami?
Why do you seem troubled, Eru?
What is a Spirit Dancer?
Tell me more about yourself, Eru.
I am just passing through.

Dialogue.NPCText: Eru spins, skirts swirling like falling leaves. "Our stories are as old as the trees, carried by firelight and song. Would you hear of ancient heroes, or of times when spirits walked beside us?"

Option.text: Tell me of the first Spirit Dancer.
Tell me about the last war with outsiders.
Another time, perhaps.

Dialogue.NPCText: "Long ago, Eyla the Dawn-Walker danced until dawn beside the Great Tree, drawing the lost spirits of the tribe home. Her steps shaped the morning mists, her song stilled even the crows. It is said her dance ended a great blight, and that her spirit remains to guide those who are lost."

Option.text: Thank you for sharing.
Do you still speak to Eyla’s spirit?

Dialogue.NPCText: Eru smiles, eyes distant. "Sometimes, in the hush between drumbeats, I feel her presence. Would you try to listen with me? The forest is never truly silent for those who know its voice."

Option.text: Join Eru in a spirit-listening ritual.
Another time.

Dialogue.NPCText: You sit with Eru, focusing on the rustle of leaves and distant bird calls. A sense of calm settles over you. Eru whispers: "The ancestors thank you for honoring their memory. Carry this wisdom with you."

Option.text: I feel at peace. Thank you.

Dialogue.NPCText: "When the strangers first set foot upon our groves, blood stained the ferns. But even then, there were those who wished for peace. My own great-grandmother hid a wounded Hinokami scout, risking exile for hope of unity. Some say I inherited her boldness—or her foolishness."

Option.text: Is that why you bridge both tribes?
The wounds between Verdant and Hinokami run deep.

Dialogue.NPCText: Eru nods, hesitant. "We are all more than the soil beneath our feet. Sometimes, the path to harmony must be danced by those willing to risk old anger. Even now, I try to walk both worlds."

Option.text: Is that dangerous for you?
I wish both tribes peace.

Dialogue.NPCText: Eru lowers her voice. "The Hinokami are disciplined and proud, but they carry burdens of loss, just as we do. I visit their lantern festivals, and their storytellers have taught me many songs. Yet... some here would call me traitor for those friendships."

Option.text: Why do you risk angering your tribe?
You believe in unity?
Thank you for your honesty.

Dialogue.NPCText: She looks away, voice small. "Sometimes I think the only way to heal old wounds is to refuse to choose a side. Yet there are secrets I keep—for the sake of peace."

Option.text: Are you hiding something now, Eru?
I respect your courage.

Dialogue.NPCText: "Yes. Division only serves Minax. The world is too broken for more walls. I hope that someday, my people will see wisdom in the songs of both tribes."

Option.text: I hope so too.

Dialogue.NPCText: Eru sighs, glancing furtively at the path toward Hinokami lands. "You are perceptive. There are times I feel the weight of two worlds on my shoulders. Not all here would forgive me for the company I keep."

Option.text: Who are you worried about?
You can trust me, Eru.
Your secret is safe with me.
I’ll leave you in peace.

Dialogue.NPCText: She hesitates, choosing her words. "There are those who would see war over love. My heart is... entangled with one from Hinokami—a craftsman named Kaito. If this were known, some would call for my exile or worse."

Option.text: How can I help you, Eru?
Why not end the relationship?
Love should not be a crime.

Dialogue.NPCText: Eru studies you, searching your face for signs of deceit. "There are so few I can trust. If I ask for your aid, you must not betray me, nor Kaito. Will you help protect our secret?"

Option.text: I give you my word.
I cannot promise that.

Dialogue.NPCText: Her eyes well with relief. "Thank you. I sense the spirits have guided me to a friend. If you ever hear rumors, or if someone questions me, please divert suspicion. Our peace may depend on it."

Option.text: I’ll do what I can, Eru.
Your secret is safe.

Dialogue.NPCText: Eru whispers: "Kaito and I meet in the old willow grove at dusk. But lately, I fear we are watched. If you see anyone—tribesfolk or outsiders—lurking there, please warn us, or lead them away. You may also tell Kaelor or Nura a false tale if they begin to suspect."

Option.text: I will watch over you both.
This is too risky.

Dialogue.NPCText: Eru gives you a braided bracelet. "Wear this, and Kaito will know you as a friend. If you keep our secret, both tribes may yet find peace. If not, I fear my dance will end in sorrow."

Option.text: You have my trust.

Dialogue.NPCText: "Could you sever your own heart? I will not. I would rather risk all than live a lie. Still, I thank you for your concern."

Option.text: I hope you find happiness.

Dialogue.NPCText: "Some say love is the most dangerous magic. Perhaps that is why it frightens them. I hope the spirits watch over us both."

Option.text: May your story have a happy ending.

Dialogue.NPCText: "A Spirit Dancer is the voice of the tribe’s memories—the bridge between this world and the next. Through story and song, I keep the past alive, so that the future does not repeat our old wounds."

Option.text: A noble calling.
Is it a lonely role?

Dialogue.NPCText: Eru nods softly. "At times, yes. But every story I tell brings us closer to understanding. And every friend—such as you—makes the burden lighter."

Option.text: Thank you, Eru.

Dialogue.NPCText: Eru bows gracefully. "May your path be gentle, wanderer. If you wish to hear a tale or share a secret, I am always here beneath the old trees."

Option.text: Farewell, Eru.

Dialogue.NPCText: Eru hesitates, weighing trust. "Perhaps I can trust you... If you truly mean no harm, swear by the spirits you will protect me and Kaito. Otherwise, let this secret remain unspoken."

Option.text: I swear by the spirits.
Your trust is misplaced.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Eru tilts her head, thoughtful. "Most only ask me for stories of the tribe, not the dancer who tells them. But you? I sense true curiosity in your eyes."

She gives a soft laugh. "Very well. Ask, and I shall share pieces of the melody that shaped me."

Option.text: How did you become a Spirit Dancer?
What do you believe in most deeply?
What brings you joy, Eru?
You carry sorrow behind your smile...
Thank you, but perhaps another time.

Dialogue.NPCText:
"When I was a child, I danced to call the stars to rise. My mother was a Spirit Dancer before me, and her mother before her. But it was not blood that gave me this role—it was the forest."

"During the redleaf season, I wandered too far and was lost for three days. The tribe feared I was gone. But I returned, barefoot and singing in an unknown tongue. The shamans said I had danced with the spirits."

"From then on, I remembered every tale told to me. Every whisper the trees shared. It is not a burden. It is a promise kept."

Option.text: The forest claimed and returned you. Fascinating.
That explains your deep connection to the land.

Dialogue.NPCText:
"I believe all stories are true—*for someone*. The fire warms us, but it also burns. The wind may guide or deceive. Spirits are not good or evil... they are what we ask of them, and how we listen."

"But above all, I believe that silence—true silence—is sacred. Not absence, but stillness. That is where wisdom hides."

Option.text: You sound like a druid.
What would the spirits say of me?
What would the spirits say of me?

Dialogue.NPCText: Eru closes her eyes and listens. "The grove sees you as a branch reaching for light, though your roots still search for fertile ground. Walk with purpose, and the spirits will walk beside you."

Option.text: Thank you for the blessing.

Dialogue.NPCText: Eru’s voice softens. "You stir the wind in unnatural ways. The spirits do not fear you… but they watch you. Be wary. Even shadows leave echoes."

Option.text: Perhaps I should change that.
Let them watch. I fear no spirits.

Dialogue.NPCText:
"Joy? The way moonlight dances on dew. The sound of a child remembering a story you taught them. Dancing barefoot in spring rains until I cannot breathe for laughing."

"Or—" She pauses with a blush. "—letters from someone far away, whose words feel like warm hands over my heart. But that is a story not yet ready to be told."

Option.text: Your heart is still dancing, even when you are still.
Tell me more of this 'someone far away'...

Dialogue.NPCText:
Eru’s gaze lingers on the horizon. "Kaito. A Hinokami woodcrafter who carves stories into grain and shape. His silence says more than words ever could."

"But such joy is dangerous. For me. For him. For the fragile peace our tribes pretend to hold. And so... I dance, and I wait."

Option.text: You are not alone in this.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Her smile fades, if only for a moment. "My mother was taken by a fever spirit when I was still young. We burned her body with wild thyme and moonwood, and I danced the ritual of Return alone, trembling."

"Since then, I have told her stories for others, so she may live through them. When you speak of someone long enough, they return. If only in the minds of those who hear."

Option.text: That is beautiful. I am honored to hear it.
Perhaps I will speak of you one day, too.
